case_data.name: Bonner v. Colby College
case_data.plaintiff_description: High school students claim denial of equal treatment and benefits accompanying opportunity to participate in athletics based on gender; including funding, supplies, travel, and coaching.
case_data.summary:
On June 6, 2003, four female students filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maine under Title IX of the Education Amendment of 1972 and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment against Colby College. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, claimed that the College violated their rights to participate in athletics based on their sex. Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that Colby College provided male athletes with more funding, newer equipment, more coaching, and a better locker room. The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief and attorney's fees.

On June 23, 2003, Colby College moved to dismiss the Equal Protection claim on the basis that, as a private college, they were not a state actor and therefore could not be sued under 48 USC 1983. On July 31, 2003, the Court (Judge John Woodcock, Jr.) granted the defendant's motion.

On February 19, 2004, the parties reached a settlement and stipulated to dismissal of the action with prejudice. While the settlement agreement was not filed, new reports state the Colby College agreed to adjust coaching assignments, remodel the women's locker room, and maintain policies and practices to ensure equivalent programs for men's and women's teams.
case_data.summary_short: On June 6, 2003, female students filed a lawsuit against Colby College under Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause. They claimed that the school discriminated against female athletes by failing to provide them with the same treatment and benefits provided to male athletes. Colby College agreed to remedy the discrimination and the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on February 19, 2004.
